reviews.review_msg: All this class teaches you is how to write a basic 5 paragraph essay and it feels just like high school again. This class being so repetitive, it felt like a never-ending 13-week nightmare. Jorge is a caring professor and gives lots of time for exams which are done at home. There is also a TA to correct your work so you get it back promptly.

Jorge's class was a repetitive wreck. We did the same thing every week for the whole semester. We were also forced to do weekly at home group papers for participation that were the same thing each week. Jorge also has a tendency to talk down to students.
Literally didn't go to lectures after the first day because its SO boring. 3 hrs of nothing related to the exams.

Easy class (reading, participation, essays) made difficult by the boredom incurred. So unengaged I actually lost French. Felt as though I was uselessly pushed to relearn how to write an essay, but with a rigorous structure one could not divert from. Good luck finding obscure themes in a limited time for essay exams if you're autistic.

Reasons not to take a class with Jorge: 1) Very disorganized 2) DOES NOT RESPOND TO E-MAILS, ever 3) Does not provide any feedback whatsoever on assignments 4) Does not correct assignments in a timely manner 5) Is not passionate and seems like he would rather be anywhere else in the world than in the classroom teaching literature

Very uninformed about feminism/women's issues, of which he talked about to a class of ALL WOMEN in a very condescending/patronizing manner, on topics with which he has literally no personal experience. Took the conversation away from the people it directly affected (women) & would make the girls who added to the convo feel dumb for even speaking.
He knows his stuff but acts like he would rather be anywhere in the world. Always last to arrive to class (late) and first to leave class at the end.

I would like to begin by saying that I love french literature. However I get the impression that Jorge is doing his very best to make all of this students hate it. He is very condescending and disrespectful to his students. He will use your questions to point out his own intelligence and insult you with impunity. Do NOT take a course with him.

Worst teacher I've had in the french department. His tests are extremely unfair, expected us to know 100+ pages from the textbook (by heart) for the test. Obviously is smart with french lit. but not suitable for teaching this class. Gave us 2 days notice of what is on the test. Thanks for making me hate literature!
The best prof I've ever had! Super kind and patient with students. Very fair grader!

Late to office hours, horribly vague criteria, replies to emails 3 days later... we receive criteria for heavy weighted assessments at the same time as the assessment starts, cutting into our time. The worst class Ive taken at SFU, would not take a class with her if I didnt have to but she is the only French lit professor at the moment.
It'd be hard to find a prof who cares more than Bettina. Not easy by any means, but you learn a lot and she is incredibly helpful. Definitely take a class with her if you can. She knows her stuff.

Bettina is a great prof! She's so smart and is so passionate about the subject. This isn't an easy class, but she is very very very clear about what she wants on her papers and exams, which definitely helps. Sometimes her lectures are long and boring, but it's still worth it to go. I would definitely take another class with her. She's a sweetheart.

SUPER helpful. Definitely not a slack course but she knows everything about everything and will help you out whenever you need it. It's a shame she only teaches the intro course - would take another one with her in a heartbeat. Bettina for president of everything.

The homework (ungraded) consists of weekly readings with questions and sometimes an additional paragraph to be written as practice for the upcoming take-home writes. These were discussed in-class (participation = 10%). I recommend doing the practice paragraphs, then asking for feedback in his office hours. He's very kind, and I enjoyed his class.

Stephen is probably the kindest man ever and clearly passionate about the course material. It was challenging at times to follow his lectures when there were few slides or visual aids but if you put in effort and participate in class you will get a decent grade.

Literally the sweetest man, but doesn't know how to make engaging lectures. Literally never seen him touch a computer, so no powerpoint slides, he instead runs around the class writing keywords on the board. He's clearly passionate, but it's hard to follow when he simply just talks about the books for 3 hours straight with no slides to  
follow.
The sweetest man I have ever met. Stephen is clearly passionate about the course which shows in his lectures and above all his relationship with students.  Highly recommend taking a course with him.
Very expressive and clearly passionate about the literature he teaches about! Very kind and helpful. Make sure to pay attention in lecture because he WILL call on you to finish his sentences, haha.
